awd_titl_txt: Nonparametric Curve Estimation in Presence of Missing Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on statistical activities motivated by medical and engineering applications in the presence of missing data, a familiar and often inevitable complication in statistical analysis. The first main activity is motivated by the analysis of functional magnet resonance images of the human brain. The project will develop and test statistical procedures that allow doctors and bioengineers to take into account missing data with potential applications in understanding the neural plasticity and developing new methods for diagnosis and treatment of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. The second main activity is the statistical analysis of radiation and drug therapy of cancer cells and finding efficient treatments for prostate and breast cancers. The third main activity is to develop new statistical methods for time series analysis with environmental applications in wastewater treatment and reducing pollution. The project has the potential for impacts on environmental, actuarial, and cancer and brain studies. Graduate students will participate in the project, and obtained results will be disseminated through publications, presentation at conferences and the distribution of free R packages.

The project focuses on several topics in nonparametric curve estimation in the presence of missing data. Firstly, missing may be destructive when based solely on the data no consistent estimation is possible, and then an exploratory sampling is needed to unlock information contained in missing data. The project will develop methodology, theory and methods of efficient (minimal cost) exploratory sampling that allows matching the performance of an oracle that knows the missing mechanism. Secondly, missing always decreases available information. The PI plans to develop theory and methods for the sequential estimation with assigned risk and minimal stopping time, which becomes an attractive and feasible remedy when a priori knowledge of the size of available observations is precluded by missing. Thirdly, the PI plans to develop a shrinking local minimax methodology for missing data and construct a new type of data-driven estimators that can attain the faster minimax rate. Lastly, the project will develop sharp minimax theory and efficient nonparametric estimator for survival analysis in the presence of missing data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Missing data and censoring are familiar and often inevitable complications in statistical analysis. The missingness and the censoring reduce information contained in data, especially in cases with high rates of missing and censoring. Further, the missingness can be destructive, when based solely on the data no consistent estimation is possible, and then an exploratory sampling is needed to unlock information contained in missing data. The intellectual merit of the work is defined by:developing theory and methodology of efficient estimation of survival function, density and regression for current status censored in presence of different types of missing;  theory of efficientestimation of a bivariate density for censored data;theory and methodology of efficient spectral density estimation and confidence bands formissing not at random time series using an extra sample with minimal assumptions,amplitude-modulated time series, sequential estimation in presence of missing data;theory and methodology of sharp minimax and adaptive to smoothness and dimensionality estimation of conditional hazard rate  for left truncated and right censored data, and multivariate mixed covariates;new methods and theory for wavelet analysis of fMRI with application toneural plasticity and  analysis of big data andlarge-p-small-n matrices; sequential estimation for multivariate regression and adaptation to smoothness and underlying dimensionality; nonparametric estimation of density with unknown support based on censored data; solving the long-standing problem of sharp-minimax estimation of  aperiodic Sobolev functions not belonging to the Sobolev ellipsoid via the proposed  data-driven polynomial-trigonometric series estimator; theory of adaptive rate optimal wavelet analysis of Big Data contaminated by large noise;the first known sharp lower bound for nonparametric regression with measurement errors in predictors; discovery and description of the curse of dimensionality in ill-posedness of a functional regression. 
Broader impact of activities is defined by  applications, work with graduate students, and publications. Statistical analysisof the UTSouthwestern Medical School fMRI experiments on neural plasticityvia the developed wavelet estimators helps to shed light on how neurons are connected.Analysis of the force of mortality for  breast cancer has shown how alpha- and beta-carotine  affect life expectancy after breast surgery.  Analysis of self-monitoring blood pressure has showed how to deal with missing observations.  Developed statistical has beed  used for analysis of municipal waste water plants and   developing new technologies for reducing greenhouse gas production by the waste.In particular, the methods have been used for analysis of the effect of cleaning agents on aerobic treatment,choosing optimal aeration diffusers,  study of fouling time of new diffusers as a function of controlled parameters of aeration process, the effect of reagents in washing milk trucks,prediction of volatility solids reduction in anaerobic tanks using first 48 hours of biogas production with the process taking 29 days, controlled nonparametric multivariate regression for mesophilic and thermophilic anaerobic digestion decreasing potent greenhouse gas emission. 
    Four graduate students, including one female student,  defended their PhD theses.  The PI's book is used in graduate classes, more than 20 papers are published including 6 with the students. The PI and his graduate  students presented results of the research at statistical meetings and seminars.  


Last Modified: 09/13/2024
Modified by: Sam Efromovich
